articles.headline: Merkel Signals That Tension Persists Over U.S. Spying
articles.snippet: At a White House meeting meant to mend fences, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said it was too soon to return to “business as usual” with the United States following disclosures that the N.S.A had eavesdropped on her phone calls.
articles.abstract: At a White House meeting meant to mend fences, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said it was too soon to return to “business as usual” with the United States following disclosures that the N.S.A had eavesdropped on her phone calls.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama tried to mend fences with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Friday, calling her “one of my closest friends on the world stage.” But Ms. Merkel replied tartly that Germany still had significant differences with the United States over surveillance practices and that it was too soon to return to “business as usual.”

articles.headline: Obama Orders Policy Review on Executions
articles.snippet: President Obama directed his attorney general to review how the death penalty is applied in the United States and called a botched execution in Oklahoma “deeply disturbing.”
articles.abstract: President Obama directed his attorney general to review how the death penalty is applied in the United States and called a botched execution in Oklahoma “deeply disturbing.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama declared this week’s botched execution in Oklahoma “deeply disturbing” and directed the attorney general on Friday to review how the death penalty is applied in the United States at a time when it has become increasingly debated.

articles.headline: G.M. Talks to Families With Claims Over Defects
articles.snippet: The number of cases, attributing wrongful death or personal injury to an ignition defect, suggest more victims than the company has acknowledged.
articles.abstract: The number of cases, attributing wrongful death or personal injury to an ignition defect, suggest more victims than the company has acknowledged.
articles.lead_paragraph: The lawyer hired by General Motors to explore compensating victims of cars with a defective ignition switch met on Friday with a representative of hundreds of people and their families who say they were affected by accidents involving the vehicles.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Accident Leads to Scrutiny of Oil Sand Production
articles.snippet: A relatively minor leak last year has led regulators in Alberta to re-examine production that uses steam under pressure to separate oil from subterranean sands.
articles.abstract: A relatively minor leak last year has led regulators in Alberta to re-examine production that uses steam under pressure to separate oil from subterranean sands.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALGARY, Alberta — In the annals of oil well blowouts and pipeline disasters, the 7,400 barrels of oily slush that oozed out of the mossy bogs of the boreal forest in northeast Alberta last summer may seem like a trivial matter.

articles.headline: Mixed Verdict in Apple-Samsung Patent Fight
articles.snippet: The dispute between technology rivals ended with an award of nearly $120 million in damages to Apple and $158,000 to Samsung.
articles.abstract: The dispute between technology rivals ended with an award of nearly $120 million in damages to Apple and $158,000 to Samsung.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — A federal jury said on Friday that Apple and Samsung had infringed on each other’s patents in some mobile devices but awarded most of the damages to Apple, in the latest court fight between the two technology giants.

articles.headline: Death Stalks Muslims as Myanmar Cuts Off Aid
articles.snippet: Myanmar’s Buddhist-led government has targeted the Rohingya people, depriving them of liberties even as it trumpets democratic reforms.
articles.abstract: Myanmar’s Buddhist-led government has targeted the Rohingya people, depriving them of liberties even as it trumpets democratic reforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: SITTWE, Myanmar — By the time the baby girl was brought to the makeshift pharmacy, her chest was heaving, her temperature soaring. The supply of oxygen that might have helped was now off limits, in a Doctors Without Borders clinic shut down by the government in February.

articles.headline: The Great Unwatched
articles.snippet: Online video ads were supposed to be a marketer’s dream. Instead, many become lost in an unruly maze.
articles.abstract: Online video ads were supposed to be a marketer’s dream. Instead, many become lost in an unruly maze.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the biggest names in Internet media have been gathering in New York City at the third annual Digital Content NewFronts, a pitch-a-thon where companies like Yahoo, AOL and Crackle — and, yes, The New York Times — trumpet their digital platforms to brands eager to reach consumers via online video ads.

articles.headline: Loans That Avoid Banks? Maybe Not
articles.snippet: Peer-to-peer finance has a new swarm of lenders: some of the same kinds of big institutions it once shunned.
articles.abstract: Peer-to-peer finance has a new swarm of lenders: some of the same kinds of big institutions it once shunned.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was that rare thing, scarcely seen in the financial world since the debut of the A.T.M. or microfinancing: an innovation to help regular people. When peer-to-peer, or P2P, lending began in the middle of the last decade, it offered an easy way for people to lend money to each other over the Internet.

articles.headline: At Bank of America, a $4 Billion Wet Blanket on the Party
articles.snippet: An accounting error has cast a shadow over a bank’s comeback — and shareholders may well want some answers at the annual meeting.
articles.abstract: An accounting error has cast a shadow over a bank’s comeback — and shareholders may well want some answers at the annual meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re a bank executive, it’s never going to be easy to tell your shareholders: Oops, we made a $4 billion mistake!

articles.headline: Behind the Masks in Ukraine, Many Faces of Rebellion
articles.snippet: A deeper look at the rebels in Ukraine offers a murky picture of their aims, motivations and connections. They appear to be Ukrainians, but they have deep ties to and affinity for Russia.
articles.abstract: A deeper look at the rebels in Ukraine offers a murky picture of their aims, motivations and connections. They appear to be Ukrainians, but they have deep ties to and affinity for Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The rebel leader spread a topographic map in front of a closed grocery store here as a Ukrainian military helicopter flew past a nearby hill. Ukrainian troops had just seized positions along a river, about a mile and a half away. The commander thought they might advance.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers and Noah Sneider

articles.headline: Some E-Cigarettes Deliver a Puff of Carcinogens
articles.snippet: New research suggests that some e-cigarettes get so hot that they can produce a carcinogenic byproduct.
articles.abstract: New research suggests that some e-cigarettes get so hot that they can produce a carcinogenic byproduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: Electronic cigarettes appear to be safer than ordinary cigarettes for one simple — and simply obvious — reason: people don’t light up and smoke them.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Hopeful Finds Tribal Tie Cuts Both Ways
articles.snippet: T. W. Shannon, a member of the Chickasaw Nation who has emerged as a formidable candidate in the Oklahoma Senate race, is a symbol to some Republicans but a target for others because of his tribal roots.
articles.abstract: T. W. Shannon, a member of the Chickasaw Nation who has emerged as a formidable candidate in the Oklahoma Senate race, is a symbol to some Republicans but a target for others because of his tribal roots.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARTLESVILLE, Okla. — T. W. Shannon will be Oklahoma’s first black senator if he wins the Republican nomination and is elected this November, but the quiet campaign stirring here about Mr. Shannon’s racial loyalties is not aimed at the African-American branch of his family tree.

articles.headline: Fight Against Sexual Assaults Holds Colleges to Account
articles.snippet: As more victims go public and more of them file formal federal complaints, activists are making shrewd use of the law and the media to force schools to change their approach to assaults.
articles.abstract: As more victims go public and more of them file formal federal complaints, activists are making shrewd use of the law and the media to force schools to change their approach to assaults.
articles.lead_paragraph: Emma Sulkowicz said she knew it would be awful to go before a disciplinary panel and describe being raped by a fellow student, but nothing prepared her for what came next. She said one of the two women on the panel, a university official, asked her, repeatedly, how the painful sex act she described was physically possible.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Kate Taylor

articles.headline: When Hitting ‘Find My iPhone’ Takes You to a Thief’s Doorstep
articles.snippet: Using GPS tracking apps, more people are taking the law into their own hands to recover stolen smartphones, a trend that has law enforcement officials concerned.
articles.abstract: Using GPS tracking apps, more people are taking the law into their own hands to recover stolen smartphones, a trend that has law enforcement officials concerned.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST COVINA, Calif. — After a boozy Saturday night, Sarah Maguire awoke the next morning to find that her iPhone was gone. Her roommate’s phone was gone, too. Were they at the bar, she wondered, or in the cab?

articles.headline: Bloomberg Gains 2 Veteran Political Journalists
articles.snippet: John Heilemann and Mark Halperin, authors of the best sellers “Game Change” and “Double Down,” will join the company to anchor Bloomberg Politics.
articles.abstract: John Heilemann and Mark Halperin, authors of the best sellers “Game Change” and “Double Down,” will join the company to anchor Bloomberg Politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Heilemann and Mark Halperin, political journalists known for their detailed, gossip-filled books on the past two presidential campaigns, will join Bloomberg in the coming days to start a new site that will focus on American politics and policy.

articles.headline: Libertarians Trail Meter Readers, Telling Town: Live Free or Else
articles.snippet: Activists in Keene, N.H., are tracking parking officers, feeding expired meters and leaving notes saying “we saved you from the king’s tariff,” all in an effort to combat the “violent monopoly” of government.
articles.abstract: Activists in Keene, N.H., are tracking parking officers, feeding expired meters and leaving notes saying “we saved you from the king’s tariff,” all in an effort to combat the “violent monopoly” of government.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEENE, N.H. — In most places, the parking enforcement officer reflects the municipal compact. Armed only with a gadget that can spit out a ticket at the forgotten drop of a dime, the officer quietly serves civic and commercial life by ensuring that meters are fed.

articles.headline: No Regrets for the Founder of Tumblr After Yahoo Sale
articles.snippet: While conceding he was “terrified” going into the deal, David Karp says he is happy with the autonomy the microblogging service has under its new owner.
articles.abstract: While conceding he was “terrified” going into the deal, David Karp says he is happy with the autonomy the microblogging service has under its new owner.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Yahoo bought Tumblr for $1.1 billion a year ago, it sent a ripple of excitement — and anxiety — through the tech industry. Would Yahoo and its recently arrived chief executive, Marissa Mayer, breathe new life into Tumblr? Or would Yahoo smother the start-up, as it did after acquiring popular young services like GeoCities and Flickr?

articles.headline: X Still Marks Sunken Spot, and Gold Awaits
articles.snippet: Loaded with treasure, the S.S. Central America sank in 1857 during a hurricane near South Carolina. After years of legal battles, a private company is finally excavating the ship.
articles.abstract: Loaded with treasure, the S.S. Central America sank in 1857 during a hurricane near South Carolina. After years of legal battles, a private company is finally excavating the ship.
articles.lead_paragraph: The discovery of sunken gold conjures up visions of instant riches: Swiss bank accounts and lazy afternoons on faraway beaches, daiquiris in hand.

articles.headline: Kiev Struggles to Break Russia’s Grip on Gas Flow
articles.snippet: A plan to skirt Russia’s state energy behemoth, Gazprom, by reverse-flowing natural gas into Ukraine has been hindered by reluctance from neighboring Slovakia, seemingly due to pressure from the Russian company.
articles.abstract: A plan to skirt Russia’s state energy behemoth, Gazprom, by reverse-flowing natural gas into Ukraine has been hindered by reluctance from neighboring Slovakia, seemingly due to pressure from the Russian company.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHASLOVTSY, Ukraine — As Ukraine tries to contain a pro-Russian insurgency convulsing its eastern region, a perhaps more significant struggle for the country hinges on what happens beneath the ground here in a placid woodland in the far west, on the border with Slovakia.

articles.headline: At Derby Day With Murdoch, Rand Paul Goes Through His Paces
articles.snippet: For Rand Paul, the would-be presidential candidate, and Rupert Murdoch, one of the most powerful Republican brokers, Saturday marked a potential turn in the 2016 campaign.
articles.abstract: For Rand Paul, the would-be presidential candidate, and Rupert Murdoch, one of the most powerful Republican brokers, Saturday marked a potential turn in the 2016 campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — On the afternoon of the Kentucky Derby, Rand Paul, the state’s junior Republican senator and likely presidential candidate, spilled out of an elevator in the exclusive Jockey Club Suites of Churchill Downs with an entourage of women with flower-adorned hats, men in seersucker suits and Rupert Murdoch.

articles.headline: A Key Player in a Scandal, V. Stiviano Feeds the Media’s Appetite
articles.snippet: If you wanted to see clearly into how all the various components of the modern media ecosystem interact, you could not come up with a better real-time experiment than the Donald Sterling story.
articles.abstract: If you wanted to see clearly into how all the various components of the modern media ecosystem interact, you could not come up with a better real-time experiment than the Donald Sterling story.
articles.lead_paragraph: Words are sometimes no match for pictures. So when I suggest that V. Stiviano may understand and avail herself of the current American media culture better than anyone, it is worth taking a look at our subject, below.

articles.headline: New Ideas in Lighting Get Closer to Market
articles.snippet: Two start-ups will offer light bulb choices that meet updated energy standards, but they will face consumers who are reluctant to change.
articles.abstract: Two start-ups will offer light bulb choices that meet updated energy standards, but they will face consumers who are reluctant to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOBURN, Mass. — Ever since government regulations began phasing out the traditional light bulb in 2012, the once-simple visit to the lighting aisle has become an exercise in navigating a dizzying array of choices and terminologies, especially for new kinds of compact fluorescents and LEDs.

articles.headline: Advertisers Seek a ‘Second Screen’ Connection With Viewers
articles.snippet: Companies try to reach multitasking television watchers through their smartphones, tablets and laptops with Twitter and Facebook posts that are relevant to popular programs.
articles.abstract: Companies try to reach multitasking television watchers through their smartphones, tablets and laptops with Twitter and Facebook posts that are relevant to popular programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent episodes of “Game of Thrones,” viewers have seen scenes of theft, rape, infanticide, cannibalism, beheading, crucifixion, castration, incest, murder and dismemberment.

articles.headline: Greenlight Asked S.E.C. for Delay on Disclosure of Micron Stake
articles.snippet: Greenlight Capital, a hedge fund headed by David Einhorn, asked the S.E.C. in November for an extra seven days before reporting a huge purchase of Micron Technology shares.
articles.abstract: Greenlight Capital, a hedge fund headed by David Einhorn, asked the S.E.C. in November for an extra seven days before reporting a huge purchase of Micron Technology shares.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Einhorn, the billionaire hedge fund manager whose stock picks are closely watched on Wall Street, is not a big fan of so-called copycat traders who simply latch onto his ideas — especially when it costs his investors money.

articles.headline: Faltering Target Parts Ways With Chief
articles.snippet: Gregg Steinhafel resigned, felled not only by a broad online attack during the holiday shopping crush, but by wooden performances at the company’s stores in Canada and on its website.
articles.abstract: Gregg Steinhafel resigned, felled not only by a broad online attack during the holiday shopping crush, but by wooden performances at the company’s stores in Canada and on its website.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Target, Gregg Steinhafel, resigned from the company on Monday, signaling the depths of the damage done by last year’s extensive breach of customer information.

articles.headline: Sotheby’s Yields to Hedge Fund Mogul and Allies
articles.snippet: Sotheby’s said on Monday that it had ended its fight with Daniel S. Loeb, agreeing to add his three director nominees to its board.
articles.abstract: Sotheby’s said on Monday that it had ended its fight with Daniel S. Loeb, agreeing to add his three director nominees to its board.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:48 p.m. | For months, Sotheby’s fought tooth and nail as the hedge fund mogul and longtime client Daniel S. Loeb waged a boardroom war against the auction house in an effort to win board seats and a change in strategy.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Town Meetings Can Have Prayer, Justices Decide
articles.snippet: In a 5-4 ruling that split the Supreme Court’s liberal and conservative members, the justices said that towns may start their sessions with sectarian prayers.
articles.abstract: In a 5-4 ruling that split the Supreme Court’s liberal and conservative members, the justices said that towns may start their sessions with sectarian prayers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a major decision on the role of religion in government, the Supreme Court on Monday ruled that the Constitution allows town boards to start their sessions with sectarian prayers. The ruling, by a 5-to-4 vote, divided the court’s more conservative members from its liberal ones, and their combative opinions reflected very different views of the role of faith in public life, in contemporary society and in the founding of the Republic.
